creator: swamin30@rediffmail.com
text:
I tried installing Apache 2.0.40 in japanese directory in Windows NT. The 
installation procedes with out any errors.I also checked the box for running as 
a service for all the Users.

 After the installation is completed, I was surprised to see that there the 
apache is not listed as the service. Later i tried to run the Apache2.exe 
manually but it stated that "syntax error at line 57 server root must be a 
valid directory". I thought this is because of the japanese character in the 
directory structure. But I am able to run the apache if installed in English 
directory.

Please help me in this regard. Advise me how to solve this issue.
with regards
Swami

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
You have to save your configuration file as UTF-8. For the future: This is a 
bug database, please address such questions to a user support forum (e.g. 
<http://httpd.apache.org/lists.html#http-users>).

And further: 2.0.40 is quite outdated. You may want to update (2.0.44 is 
current).

Thanks for using Apache.
Thanks for the response. But your suggestion of UTF-8 also does not work.
creator: swamin30@rediffmail.com

text:
Well,

- make sure, you're actually using an unicode filesystem (NTFS)
- make sure, the utf-8 encoding is correct and the directory is actually valid
- check your windows registry, there may be paths given from there, but I'm not  
  sure, how the strings have to be encoded there. Probably someone else knows 
  better (One of our Bills should be able to tell us, I'd guess)
- please check if it's reproducable with the current 2.0.44.

Thanks.

text:
Dear Andre Malo,

We have tried installing Apache 2.0.44 in a chinese directory, in that also we
faced the same issue.
But when saving the httpd.conf file, in the UTF-8 format makes it works. So in
order to run the Apache server installed in non english directory we have to
save the httpd.conf in UTF-8 format. Am I right.

Thanks for the response,
Swami
Yes, you must save the configuration file as UTF-8 to serve from a UTF-8 Directory.
